 File path: python/pyarrow/parquet.py

 @@ -124,11 +124,14 @@ class ParquetFile(object):
     memory_map : boolean, default True
         If the source is a file path, use a memory map to read file, which can
         improve performance in some environments
+    enable_buffered_stream : int, default 0
+        The size of the temporary read buffer.
 
 Review comment:
   This comment isn't clear about what the argument is for.
   
   "If positive, perform read buffering when deserializing individual column chunks. Otherwise IO calls are unbuffered"
   
   Other kinds of IO when reading the file won't be affected by this

wesm commented on issue #5380: ARROW-6253: [Python] Expose "enable_buffered_stream" option from parquet::ReaderProperties in pyarrow.parquet.read_table
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5380#issuecomment-532020355
 
 
   @pitrou yes, it does -- buffering in reading Parquet files is about _memory efficiency_, not performance. I think I've already explained this elsewhere but here is is once more for the record =) 
   
   The problem is that a row group can be 1GB or more on disk. If you don't use buffering, then depending on how you're reading the file (e.g. scanning a small batch of rows at a time), you may load the entire serialized row group into RAM. You can see in this function here
   
   https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/master/cpp/src/parquet/properties.cc#L28
   
   There are two code paths:
   
   * Load the entire serialized data into memory with `ReadAt`
   * Use buffering instead to read only what's need to return the next X rows
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the

URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5380#issuecomment-532020355
 
 
   @pitrou yes, it does -- buffering in reading Parquet files is about _memory efficiency_, not performance. I think I've already explained this elsewhere but here it is once more for the record =) 
   
   The problem is that a row group can be 1GB or more on disk. If you don't use buffering, then depending on how you're reading the file (e.g. scanning a small batch of rows at a time), you may load the entire serialized row group into RAM. You can see in this function here
   
   https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/master/cpp/src/parquet/properties.cc#L28
   
   There are two code paths:
   
   * Load the entire serialized data into memory with `ReadAt`
   * Use buffering instead to read only what's need to return the next X rows
